newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel delays liberalisation for steel products.
newsitem.headline: Israel delays liberalisation for steel products.

text.p: Israel's Finance Ministry and the Ministry of Trade and Industry have decided to slow down the liberalisation process for some steel products, sources in the Finance Ministry said.
According to the sources, the ministries have bowed to pressure from local industry and agreed to postpone lowering customs duties for two kinds of steel products by a year.
Local companies said they had difficulty competing against products imported from countries with which Israel does not have free trade agreements.
The final stage of a five-year liberalisation programme for most industrial products, including steel, will come into effect on September 1.
At the end of the liberalisation programme in September customs on raw materials will be eight percent and 12 percent on finished and semi-finished products.
The liberalisation process for wood products, ceramics, footware, cables and fertilisers, considered to be sensitive to competition, will end on September 1, 1998.
